title: MP Anne-Marie Trevelyan one of 57 Tories to launch rebellion against Chancellor's 'Brexit Budget'
text:
MP Anne-Marie Trevelyan one of 57 Tories to launch rebellion against Chancellor's 'Brexit Budget' 18:30, 15 Jun 2016 By Jonathan Walker The Berwick MP has condemned George Osborne's threat to raise taxes if Britain decides to leave the EU on June 23 Shares Get daily news by email Anne-Marie Trevelyan 
A North East Conservative MP has joined an extraordinary rebellion against Tory Chancellor George Osborne - and said she will vote down his emergency Budget if Britain leaves the EU . 
Mr Osborne has launched a last-ditch attempt to warn against voting ‘leave’ in the EU referendum on June 23, by claiming it would force him to put up taxes. 
The Chancellor said the economic damage caused by leaving would mean he had to put up the basic rate of income tax from 20p for every pound earned to 22p, while the top rate would rise 3p to 43p and inheritance tax would go up 5p to 45p. 
But in a sign that the EU referendum has provoked civil war in the Conservative Party, no fewer than 57 Conservative MPs immediately announced they would vote down the budget. 
They include Berwick MP Anne-Marie Trevelyan, who helped draft a statement signed by the Tory rebels. 
It means the Chancellor could face defeat in the Commons - almost certainly forcing him to resign - unless he could convince Labour to support his plans or at least to abstain. The Conservative Government has an effective majority of 17. 
Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne (L) and former Chancellor Alistair Darling attend a pro-Remain event at the Hitachi Rail Europe plant on June 15, 2016 in Ashford, England 
And the statement makes it clear Conservative MPs are ready to force Mr Osborne out of office, warning his position would be “untenable” if he tried to carry out his plans. 
The statement said: “It is absurd to say that if people vote to take back control from the EU that he would want to punish them in this way. 
“We do not believe that he would find it possible to get support in Parliament for these proposals to cut the NHS, our police forces and our schools.” 
It continued: “If he were to proceed with these proposals, the Chancellor’s position would become untenable. This is a blatant attempt to talk down the market and the country. 
“The Chancellor risks doing damage to the British economy in his bid to win this political campaign.” 
Mrs Trevelyan, who is supporting the Leave campaign, said: “The key point is that we passed a law not to put up taxation this Parliament, so this sort of scaremongering budget is nonsensical. 
“I hope that people vote on June 23 on the basis of getting back control of our taxation, sovereignty and protecting our democracy.” 
But a defiant Mr Osborne insisted he would have no choice but to act to prevent “chaos” in the public finances and “huge” economic instability. 
“No Conservative wants to raise taxes - least of all me,” he told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme. 
“But, equally, Conservatives understand - and, indeed, I suspect many Labour politicians understand - that you cannot have chaos in your public finances. 
“You have to deal with the hole that would emerge if we quit the EU and we would have to take the necessary measures. 
“The Conservative Government would do what was needed to deal with huge instability in our economy and, of course, the chaos in the public finances.” 
His planned emergency budget was published jointly with Alistair Darling, the former Labour Chancellor , and appears to be a response to opinion polls suggesting the leave campaign could win the referendum. 
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn is backing calls to remain in the EU, but appeared to condemn the Chancellor’s plans as he told the House of Commons that Labour would vote against any “austerity budget”. 
Labour has its own divisions over Europe, after senior figures including Deputy Leader Tom Watson said a future Labour or Conservative Government should attempt to end unrestricted free movement of people in the EU and convince other countries to support restrictions on immigration. 
Mr Corbyn appears to disagree, telling website Buzzfeed he would “absolutely” defend the EU’s rules on free movement of workers. 
He said: “It’s intrinsic to the European Union that there has to be free movement of people.” The European Union debate
